message.content: We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The symptoms suggest a bleeding disorder, and the lack of agglutination with ristocetin suggests von Willebrand disease (vWD). vWD can be inherited in an autosomal dominant or recessive pattern, but since the mode of transmission is not specified in the question, we assume that autosomal recessive is the most likely answer.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The symptoms suggest a bleeding disorder, and the inability of the blood to clot even with the addition of normal plasma suggests a deficiency in factor VIII or IX, which are autosomal recessive disorders. X-linked dominant and recessive disorders affect males more severely than females, so they are less likely to be the mode of transmission in this case. Mitochondrial transmission is associated with certain types of genetic disorders, but not with bleeding disorders.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The symptoms, including recurrent nosebleeds, prolonged bleeding, and lack of agglutination with ristocetin, suggest von Willebrand disease. This condition is most commonly inherited in an autosomal recessive manner.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The symptoms and the patient's bleeding disorder suggest von Willebrand disease, which is a genetic bleeding disorder that is often inherited in an autosomal dominant fashion. It can also be autosomal recessive or X-linked recessive, but the question specifically mentions autosomal recessive.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The patient’s symptoms, including recurrent nosebleeds and prolonged bleeding, suggest a bleeding disorder such as von Willebrand disease (VWD). VWD is often inherited in an autosomal dominant or recessive pattern. X-linked dominant and recessive patterns are less likely to be the cause in this patient, as they mostly affect males and there is no indication of a family history. Mitochondrial inheritance is also less likely in this case, as it is usually associated with metabolic disorders and not bleeding disorders. The lack of response to adding normal plasma also supports a diagnosis of VWD, as this would be expected to correct the bleeding if the patient had a clotting factor deficiency.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The symptoms and laboratory findings suggest a bleeding disorder, most likely von Willebrand disease. It can be inherited in an autosomal dominant or recessive pattern, but autosomal recessive is more common. No information suggests a mitochondrial or X-linked inheritance pattern.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The symptoms of frequent prolonged nosebleeds and bleeding through multiple pieces of gauze suggest von Willebrand disease, which is most commonly inherited in an autosomal recessive pattern. The lack of agglutination with ristocetin confirms the diagnosis.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The symptoms suggest that the patient may have a bleeding disorder. The lack of agglutination with ristocetin and no correction with normal plasma suggest a possible diagnosis of von Willebrand disease, which is an autosomal recessive disorder.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The symptoms described suggest that the patient has a clotting disorder. The lack of agglutination with ristocetin and the addition of normal plasma suggest a diagnosis of Glanzmann thrombasthenia, which is an autosomal recessive disorder affecting platelet function.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The symptoms and history of recurrent nosebleeds suggest a bleeding disorder. The inability to obtain agglutination with ristocetin and normal plasma suggests von Willebrand disease (vWD), an autosomal recessive bleeding disorder. The other options are not associated with vWD.
